Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This Future Forward Scholarship Program (F²SP) builds on a prior, highly successful scholarship program at Del Mar College, a Hispanic-serving, two-year institution, by supporting STEM students to complete applied science degrees to enter the workforce and/or associate degrees for transfer to four-year institutions. Ultimately, this scholarship program is supporting at least 88 majors in the fields of Biotechnology, Electrical Engineering, Engineering Technology, Geology, Mathematics, Mechanical Engineering, or Physics. F²SP provides financial support in addition to academic and social support, actively engaging academically talented and financially needy students from underrepresented STEM populations including women, Hispanics, differently abled students and Veterans by addressing the following program objectives:
- Create a "math cohort" with STEM-focused curriculum for college algebra, trigonometry and calculus I to bridge the gap between math, physics and engineering.
- Increase the number of students declaring majors in Biotechnology, Mechanical Engineering, and Engineering Technology through a campus awareness campaign.
- Increase the number of skilled graduates in technical areas of need such as Engineering Technology.
- Increase the number of students receiving Associate's degrees in STEM disciplines.
- Increase the number of students transferring to baccalaureate degree programs in STEM.
- Provide shadowing and internship opportunities for scholarship students.
- Provide information to all advisors on STEM majors and careers.
- Decrease the number of hours scholarship students work.

Scholarship students are recruited from: the Educational Service Center Region 2 area of Texas, which includes 42 public school districts; private and charter schools; nonprofit organizations such as the Women's Shelter, Salvation Army and VA Clinic; and from currently enrolled undecided undeclared and Liberal Arts students. Student support programs in place at Del Mar College, coupled with a pilot "math cohort" creating a learning community addressing fundamental concepts needed by all STEM majors, provide a strong foundation for scholarship recipients. The cohort of scholarship recipients is also extensively supported by STEM faculty through mentoring, intrusive advising, degree monitoring and personal counseling.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Del Mar College received a NSF S-STEM grant “Future Forward Scholarship Program” award for $599,635 with a start date of 8/15/2011. The grant provided funding to support financially needy students majoring in the following STEM fields: biotechnology, biology, computer science, computer information systems, chemistry, electrical engineering, mathematics, mechanical engineering, geographic information systems, geology and physics. The original grant was funded for 4 years (2011-2015). A no cost extension was requested and approved for the 2015-2016 year.

Our goals were to increase the number of students majoring in STEM, the number of students completing their degrees, and the number of students transferring to a 4-year institution. To achieve these goals over 100 students majoring in STEM were awarded scholarships for a total of over $500,000. The S-STEM program targeted first-generation college, low income and underrepresented minority students.  Students were awarded scholarships averaging $1,500 to $3,000 for one semester of study.  To enhance their experiences, students were also provided extracurricular opportunities in research at such sites as the Lawrence Berkeley National Lab, various USDA locations and Texas A&M University-Kingsville. Students presented results of their research at national meetings, conferences and workshops. The program also improved S-STEM scholars academic and transfer through counseling, tutoring and social activities. Scholars were hired as student assistants, peer tutors and mentors to assist the Program Coordinator in providing new incoming students assistance with the registration process, time management and scheduling of classes and providing information on all the free services. Overall the program was effective in helping students achieve success.
